docs.lead_paragraph: Congressional negotiators and the White House closed in on a deal late Monday on a $1.1 trillion government-wide spending bill to stave off a shutdown, and a tax package extending dozens of breaks.

docs.lead_paragraph: It's crunch time to sign up for coverage under President Barack Obama's health care law. The website works much better now, but rising premiums and shaken faith among insurers have cast new shadows.

docs.abstract: Connecticut may raise the age of those who qualify for juvenile court to 21. Is that a good idea?

docs.lead_paragraph: A careful plan to smooth the transition to health care reform has been disrupted.

headline.main: Senator Rubio Makes Life Tough for Small Insurers

docs.abstract: Editorial argues Senate should block rider introduced by Sen Marco Rubio that would prevent government from covering shortfalls in revenue for small health insurers; asserts measure would disrupt fledgling market, benefiting big insurers and burdening patients by driving out smaller rivals and forcing others to raise premiums.
docs.snippet: A careful plan to smooth the transition to health care reform has been disrupted.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: The 2010 death of Leonard Strickland would have probably been forgotten by all but the officers and inmates at Clinton Correctional Facility. Then a breakout brought attention to the prison’s secrets.

headline.main: An Inmate Dies, and No One Is Punished
headline.print_headline: A New York Inmate Dies, and No One Is Punished

docs.abstract: Review of internal reports, log books and video from Clinton Correctional Facility in Dannemora, NY, as well as witness accounts, offer insight into 2010 death of inmate Leonard Strickland; Strickland's death is often cited by prisoners as example of savage beatings guards sometimes inflict on prisoners; circumstances surrounding his death would likely have remained unknown had it not been for attention paid to prison in wake of June escape by two murderers.
docs.snippet: The 2010 death of Leonard Strickland would have probably been forgotten by all but the officers and inmates at Clinton Correctional Facility. Then a breakout brought attention to the prison’s secrets.

byline.original: By MICHAEL WINERIP and MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ

docs.lead_paragraph: The White House and top lawmakers want to wrap up a year's worth of budget work and let Congress adjourn this coming week until 2016. There are two major bills: A $1.1 trillion government-wide spending measure and a broad renewal of expiring tax breaks for businesses and individuals that could cost hundreds of billions of dollars over the next decade.

headline.main: Despair Over Gun Deaths Is Not an Option

docs.lead_paragraph: After a rocky life in the South, a Brooklyn resident became one of the first New Yorkers to undergo gender reassignment surgery paid for by Medicaid.

headline.main: ‘A Whole New Being’: How Kricket Nimmons Seized the Transgender Moment

docs.abstract: Profile of Kricket Jerna Nimmons, one of first low-income New Yorkers to undergo gender reassignment surgery paid for by Medicaid; Nimmons, who is black and was raised in rural South, has undergone long and fraught journey marked by discrimination, abuse and illness to arrive at pivotal moment; availability of procedure to Nimmons reflects changing attitudes in society and medical profession.
docs.snippet: After a rocky life in the South, a Brooklyn resident became one of the first New Yorkers to undergo gender reassignment surgery paid for by Medicaid.
